Billy_Edd_Wheeler:
{{Short description|American singer-songwriter (1932–2024)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}} {{Sources|date=September 2024}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Billy Edd Wheeler | image = | caption = | image_size = | birth_name = Billy Edward Wheeler | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date |1932|12|09}} | birth_place = [[Boone County, West Virginia]], U.S. | origin = [[Whitesville, West Virginia]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2024|9|16|1932|12|9}} | death_place = [[Swannanoa, North Carolina]], U.S. | instrument = Guitar | genre = {{hlist|[[Folk music|Folk]]|[[Country music|country]]}} | occupation = Singer-songwriter, playwright | years_active = 1964–2012 | label = {{hlist|[[Kapp Records|Kapp]]|[[United Artists Records|United Artists]]|[[RCA Records|RCA]]|Radio Cinema|NSD}} | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Billy Edward Wheeler'''[http://www.spencerleigh.demon.co.uk/Interview_Wheeler.htm Spencer Leigh interview] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080602145208/http://www.spencerleigh.demon.co.uk/Interview_Wheeler.htm |date=June 2, 2008 }} (December 9, 1932 – September 16, 2024) was an American songwriter, performer, writer, and visual artist. His songs include "[[Jackson (song)|Jackson]]" ([[Grammy]] award winner for [[Johnny Cash]] and [[June Carter]]) "[[The Reverend Mr. Black]]", "Desert Pete", "Ann", "[[High Flying Bird (song)|High Flyin' Bird]]", "The Coming of the Roads", "[[It's Midnight (song)|It’s Midnight]]", "Ode to the Little Brown Shack Out Back", "Coal Tattoo", "Winter Sky", and "[[Coward of the County]]" (which inspired a 1981 television movie of the same name) and have been performed by over 160 artists including [[Judy Collins]], [[Jefferson Airplane]], [[Bobby Darin]], [[Richie Havens]], [[The Kingston Trio]], [[Neil Young]], [[Kenny Rogers]], [[Hazel Dickens]], [[Florence and the Machine]], [[Kathy Mattea]], [[Nancy Sinatra]], and [[Elvis Presley]]. "Jackson" was also recorded by [[Joaquin Phoenix]] and [[Reese Witherspoon]] for the movie ''[[Walk the Line]]''. His song "Sassafras" was covered in the folk rock era by [[Modern Folk Quartet]] and [[The West Coast Pop Art Experimental Band]]. Wheeler was the author-composer of eight plays and musicals, a folk opera (''Song of the Cumberland Gap''), commissioned by the [[National Geographic Society]], and three outdoor dramas: the long-running ''Hatfields & McCoys'' at [[Beckley, West Virginia]], ''Young Abe Lincoln'' at [[Lincoln_State_Park#Lincoln_Amphitheatre|Lincoln Amphitheatre]], [[Lincoln City, Indiana]], and ''Johnny Appleseed'', at [[Mansfield, Ohio]]. He has authored six books of humor, four with [[Loyal Jones]] of [[Berea, Kentucky]]: ''Laughter in Appalachia'', ''Hometown Humor USA'', ''Curing the Cross-Eyed Mule'', and ''More Laughter in Appalachia'', and two as sole author: ''Outhouse Humor'', and ''Real Country Humor / Jokes from Country Music Personalities''. His first novel, ''Star of Appalachia'', was published in January 2004, and his second, co-written with [[Ewel Cornett]], ''Kudzu Covers Manhattan'', in 2005. ''Song of a Woods Colt'', a book of poetry, was published in 1969. ''Travis and Other Poems of the Swannanoa Valley (With Some Poems and Prayers by Dr. Henry W. Jensen)'' was published in 1977. He was the featured author in ''Appalachian Heritage'' magazine's 2008 winter issue, which included 16 of his original paintings. [[North Carolina]]’s ''[[Our State]]'' magazine featured him in its December 2007 issue. In 2018, Wheeler published a book of memoirs entitled ''Hotter Than A Pepper Sprout, a Hillybilly poet's journey from Appalachia to Yale to writing hits for Elvis, Johnny Cash & More''. ==Biography== Wheeler was born on December 9, 1932, in [[Boone County, West Virginia]]. He graduated from [[Warren Wilson College]] in 1953, and [[Berea College]] in 1955.{{cite web |last1=Manheim |first1=James |title=Billy Edd Wheeler: Biography |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/billy-edd-wheeler-mn0000767622 |website=allmusic.com |access-date=December 19, 2019}} After serving as a student pilot in the Navy, he served as Alumni Director of Berea College. Wheeler recorded a couple of albums for [[Monitor Records (New York)|Monitor Records]], then from 1961 to 1962 he attended the [[Yale School of Drama]], majoring in playwriting. With Ewel Cornett, he co-wrote the musical ''Hatfields and McCoys'', which has been performed annually since 1970 by Theatre West Virginia in the Grandview Cliffside Amphitheatre (part of the [[New River Gorge National River]] area).{{cite web |title=Theatre West Virginia 2005 Program |url=http://www.theatrewestvirginia.com/files/program2005.pdf |publisher=Theatre West Virginia |access-date=December 19, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061119181326/http://www.theatrewestvirginia.com/files/program2005.pdf |archive-date=November 19, 2006 |url-status=dead}}{{cite web |title=Production History |url=http://theatrewestvirginia.com/production-history/ |publisher=Theatre West Virginia |access-date=December 19, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150511153315/http://theatrewestvirginia.com/production-history/ |archive-date=May 11, 2015 |url-status=dead}} He was married to the former Mary Mitchell Bannerman. They had two adult children, Lucy and Travis, and lived in [[Swannanoa, North Carolina]]. In the 1968 book by Milt Okun ''Something to Sing About: the personal choices of America's folk singers'',New York: Macmillan Company {{ISBN|978-0-02-592820-6}}; pp. 192-94 Wheeler's choice was "Turtle Dove" ("[[Fare Thee Well (song)|Fare Thee Well]]"). He died at his home in [[Swannanoa, North Carolina]], on September 16, 2024, at the age of 91.{{Cite web|url=https://www.wtrf.com/west-virginia/west-virginia-native-songwriter-billy-edd-wheeler-dies-at-91/|title=West Virginia native, songwriter Billy Edd Wheeler dies at 91|website=Wtrf.com|date=September 17, 2024|access-date=September 21, 2024}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable" !
